properties.title: Apache James Server 3 - Quick Start for Cassandra backend

section.name: Quick Start for Cassandra backend
section.p: The goal of the document is to allow anyone to start with James on Docker as an operational mail server.
The method described bellow should not be used in production.
section.source:
Step 0: Requirements ####################
* JRE 1.5+ * root (linux/unix) or Administrator (Windows) * libc6 (linux) * 512MB RAM (launches with -Xmx512M - can use less, can need more, depending on load) * Docker 1.7.1+
Step 1: Download #################
* Clone the James git repository
$ git clone https://github.com/apache/james.git
* Then go to the Cassandra container folder
$ cd james/container/cassandra-guice
Step 2: Deploy ##############
2.1. Deploy Cassandra (optional) You may skip this part if you already have a running Cassandra on your network.
$ docker run --name=cassandra cassandra
2.2. Deploy ElasticSearch (optional) You may skip this part if you already have a running ElasticSearch on your network.
$ docker run --name=elasticsearch elasticsearch:1.5.2
2.3.Build the docker image
$ docker build --tag james-cassandra .
Step 3: Configure #################
* Follow the Cassandra guice configuration documentation. * We need to provide the key we will use for TLS. For obvious reasons, this is not provided in this git.
Copy your TSL keys to ./conf/keystore or generate it using :
$ keytool -genkey -alias james -keyalg RSA -keystore ./conf/keystore
Step 4: Start #############
* Run the docker container
$ docker run --hostname HOSTNAME -p "25:25" -p "110:110" -p "143:143" -p "465:465" -p "587:587" -p "993:993" --link cassandra:cassandra --link elasticsearch:elasticsearch --name james-cassandra -t james-cassandra
Where : - HOSTNAME is the hostname you want to give to your James container. This DNS entry will be used to send mail to your James server.
Step 5: Create Domains and Users ################################
Time to add domains and users.
$ docker exec james-cassandra /root/james-server-app-3.0.0-beta5-SNAPSHOT/bin/james-cli.sh -h 127.0.0.1 -p 9999 adddomain DOMAIN
Where : - DOMAIN is the domain you want to add.
$ docker exec james-cassandra /root/james-server-app-3.0.0-beta5-SNAPSHOT/bin/james-cli.sh -h 127.0.0.1 -p 9999 adduser USER_MAIL_ADDRESS PASSWORD
Where : - USER_MAIL_ADDRESS is the mail address that will be used by this user. - PASSWORD is the password that will be used by this user.
Step 6: Test ############
$ telnet HOSTNAME 25 Trying HOSTNAME... Connected to HOSTNAME. Escape character is '^]'. 220 172.16.1.131 SMTP Server (JAMES SMTP Server 3.0-beta4) ready Sat, 6 Nov 2010 17:31:33 +0100 (CET) ehlo test 250-172.16.1.131 Hello test (aoscommunity.com [127.0.0.1]) 250-PIPELINING 250-ENHANCEDSTATUSCODES 250 8BITMIME mail from:<YOUR_NAME@YOUR_DOMAIN> 250 2.1.0 Sender <YOUR_NAME@YOUR_DOMAIN> OK rcpt to:<YOUR_NAME@YOUR_DOMAIN> 250 2.1.5 Recipient <YOUR_NAME@YOUR_DOMAIN> OK data 354 Ok Send data ending with <CRLF>.<CRLF> subject: test
this is a test . 250 2.6.0 Message received quit Connection closed by foreign host.
Step 7: Manage ##############
7.1. Manage via james-cli
usage: $ docker exec james-cassandra /root/james-server-app-3.0.0-beta5-SNAPSHOT/bin/james-cli.sh -h 127.0.0.1 -p 9999
Available commands: adduser </username> </password> removeuser </username> listusers adddomain </domainname> removedomain </domainname> listdomains
7.2. Manage via JMX
* Launch jconsole (or any other JMX client) and connect on URL=service:jmx:rmi:///jndi/rmi://localhost:HOSTNAME/jmxrmi * Select the MBeans tab and open the org.apache.james node to view attributes and execute operations.
Step 8: Monitor ###############
* Monitor the ./log/james-server.log log file.
* Monitor via JMX (launch any JMX client and connect to URL=service:jmx:rmi:///jndi/rmi://HOSTNAME:9999/jmxrmi)
* Check ./var folder usage
mail +-error +-address-error +-relay-denied +-spam
store +-maildir +-derby +-jackrabbit +-activemq +-brokers +-james +-blob-transfer +-outgoing +-spool
* Check /tmp folder usage
